questions.text: What is the total number of airway divisions present in between trachea and alveolar sacs?
questions.solution:
The total number of airway generations present in between the trachea and alveolar sac is 23.

The tracheobronchial tree is divided into multiple generations based on Weibel’s lung model. It begins at the trachea (designated as zero) and ends with alveoli (last generation). There are 2 zones:

  • Conducting zone
    • Consists of the first 16 generations
    • Incapable of gas exchange
  • Respiratory zone
    • Consists of the last 7 generations (17-23)
    • Capable of gas exchange

 Terminal bronchiole is the transition point between the conducting and respiratory zone.

questions.text: Which among the following has the highest airway resistance?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, bronchi (medium-sized airway) offer maximum resistance.

The best answer here is bronchi, as all the other options suggest smaller airways, while bronchi are the only medium-sized airway.

Airflow can be derived from Poiseuille-Hagen formula: 

Q =π ΔPr4/8ηL

Where

  • Q is the flow rate
  • π is pie symbol
  • ΔP is the pressure difference
  • r is radius
  • η is viscosity
  • L is length

Also,

Flow rate (Q) = pressure difference (ΔP)/ resistance (R).

Therefore, substituting this in Poiseuille- Hagen formula,

ΔP/ R = π ΔPr4/8ηl

1/R = π r4/8ηl

R = 8ηl/ π r4

Therefore it can be derived that airway resistance is inversely proportional to the radius by the power of four.

With Poiseuille- Hagen formula we might feel that the smallest airways are the major site of resistance. However, the contribution by the smallest airways is very little to the overall total resistance. This is because, the airway branches in each generation exist in parallel rather than in series. As the parallel branching increases, the resistance decreases. (Total cross-sectional diameter of small airways put together is high). Thus the overall resistance of the small airways is very small. Also, airflow velocity decreases substantially as the effective cross-sectional area increases (i.e., the flow becomes laminar).

Other factors affecting airway resistance :

  • Lung volume, as lung volume increases the resistance decreases and vice versa. Lung volume increases the transairway pressure thus increasing the caliber of the airway.
  • Airway mucus, edema, and contraction of bronchial smooth muscle increase the airway resistance. Its clinical application is seen in asthma, bronchitis, and emphysema
  • The density and viscosity of inspired gas also contribute to airway resistance. A gas with more density imparts more resistance.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy with shortness of breath was diagnosed with chronic inflammation of conducting airways. Which of the following is not a feature of the affected structure?

choices.text: Includes first 16 generations starting from trachea
Secrete variety of molecules that aid in lung defence
Membrane bound organelles namely lamellar bodies are present

questions.solution:
Chronic inflammation of conducting airways is suggestive of asthma. Lamellar bodies are storage bodies of surfactant present in the alveoli and not the conducting airway.

The conducting airways form the first 16 generations from the trachea to the terminal bronchial. It is lined by pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelium. It also consists of smooth muscles which are responsible for bronchoconstriction and dilatation. It also consists of other specialized cells such as:

  • Basal cells - stem cells
  • Clara/Club cells - specialized epithelial cells (non-ciliated cuboidal cells) that:
    • Functions as stem cells
    • Helps in lung defense.

The conducting airways secrete several substances that in lung defense such as:

  • Secretory immunoglobins - IgA
  • Collectins - surfactant protein(SP)-A and SP-D
  • Defensins
  • Reactive oxygen species
  • Reactive nitrogen species.

questions.text: An elderly smoker who presented with an acute exacerbation of COPD is administered salbutamol. Which one of the following substances has a similar mechanism of action?
questions.solution:
Salbutamol, a short-acting beta (adrenergic) agonist (SABA) is a bronchodilator. Similarly, vasoactive intestinal polypeptide (VIP) is also a bronchodilator. Along with dynorphin, it is part of the non-adrenergic non-cholinergic (NANC) inhibitory system.

Bronchial innervation:

Site Type of receptor Effect
Sympathetic system
Tracheal and bronchial smooth muscle β2 Relaxation
Bronchial glands

α1

β2

Reduce secretion

Increase secretion
Parasympathetic system (more predominant)
Tracheal and bronchial smooth muscle M2, M3 Contraction
Bronchial glands M2, M3 Stimulation

Other potent bronchoconstrictors are histamine and leukotrienes.

Clinical relevance:

  • Methacholine sensitivity test or Airway hyperresponsiveness test: Methacholine which is similar to acetylcholine causes exaggerated bronchoconstriction in case of bronchial asthma. 
  • 5-Lipoxygenase inhibitor (5-LOX inhibitor-Zileuton), selective CysLT-receptor antagonists (Cys leukotriene receptor antagonist-zafirlukast, pranlukast, and montelukast), and β2 receptor agonists are used in the treatment of asthma.

questions.text: Which of the following cells secrete surfactant in lungs?
questions.solution:
Type 2 pneumocytes secrete surfactant in the lungs.

Alveolar Lining Epithelial Cells

Two types

  • Type I cells – The primary lining cells of the alveoli (squamous epithelium); Helps in gas exchange
  • Type II cells  – Granular pneumocytes produce surfactant

Type II cells make 60% of epithelial cells in alveoli but type I cells form 95% of the total surface area because of its flat surface.

Type II cells are stem cells which help in replenishing damaged Type 1 pneumocytes in conditions like drug-induced pulmonary toxicity by amiodarone, bleomycin etc. 

Other cells – Pulmonary alveolar macrophages (PAMs/type 3 alveolar cells), lymphocytes, plasma cells, neuroendocrine cells (APUD cells-Amine precursor uptake and decarboxylation), and mast cells.

Major surfactant is dipalmitoylphosphatidylcholine i.e Lecithin. Sphingomyelin is a minor surfactant.

The surfactant is a surface-active agent in water, which means that it greatly reduces the surface tension of water.

Pulmonary surfactant is produced by type 2 pneumocytes.

Most important components are

  • Phospholipid - dipalmitoylphosphatidylcholine (DPPC) also known as Dipalmitoyl Lecithin. Lecithin is the most abundant lipid in surfactant.
  • Phosphatidylglycerol- minor component
  • Surfactant apoproteins
  • Calcium ions.
  • 4 unique apoproteins of surfactant: surfactant protein (SP)-A, SP-B, SP-C, and SP-D.

Clinical relevance:

  • Tests to assess fetal lung maturity:
    • L/S ratio i.e. Lecithin/Sphingomyelin ratio: Ratio ≥ 2 is considered normal.
    • Shake test/Bubble test/Clement test: Formation of stable foam in the presence of surfactant.
    • Phosphatidylglycerol levels in Amniotic fluid
  • Autosomal dominant familial interstitial lung disease has absent surfactant protein SP-C.
  • Pulmonary alveolar proteinosis - Autoantibody against GM-CSF which is involved in clearance of surfactant.

questions.text: All are true of surfactant except_____

choices.text: Deficiency of surfactant causes  Infant Respiratory Distress Syndrome
Helps prevents alveolar collapse according to Bernoulli's principle
Decrease in surfactant increases the work of breathing

questions.solution:
Surfactant helps to  prevent alveolar collapse according to Law of Laplace.(Not Bernoulli's)

Physiologic advantages of surfactant

  • By reducing surface tension it increases lung compliance
  • Reduces the lung's tendency to recoil
  • Helps to keep the alveoli dry
  • Helps to prevent pulmonary edema (Option A)

The surface tension generates a pressure that tends to collapse the sphere.

In accordance with Law of Laplace - P=2T/r, where
P - Collapsing pressure on alveolus (dynes/cm2) or Pressure required to keep alveolus open (dynes/cm2)
T = Surface tension (dynes/cm)
r = Radius of the alveolus (cm).

Collapsing pressure is inversely related to radius i.e. large alveolus (one with a large radius) will have a low collapsing pressure and therefore will require only minimal pressure to keep it open. On the other hand, a small alveolus (one with a small radius) will have a high collapsing pressure and require more pressure to keep it open.

By reducing surface tension, surfactant reduces the collapsing pressure for a given radius.

Option B: Surfactant deficiency is an important cause of infant respiratory distress syndrome (IRDS) also known as hyaline membrane disease, the serious pulmonary disease that develops in infants born before their surfactant system is functional.

  • In IRDS, there is high surface tension in the lungs resulting in atelectasis
  • Also, there is retention of fluid in the lungs.
    • During fetal life, Cl- is secreted with fluid by the pulmonary epithelial cells. At birth, there is a shift to Na+ reabsorption by these cells via ENaC and fluid is absorbed along with Na+. Prolonged immaturity of ENaC contributes to pulmonary edema in IRDS.

Option D: Surfactant increases lung compliance, which reduces the work of expanding the lungs during inspiration. Increasing the compliance of the lungs reduces the collapsing force at any given volume so that it is easier for the lungs to expand.

questions.text: A young lady at 35 weeks of gestation is at high risk of preterm delivery in the next 7 days. She is started on antenatal corticosteroid therapy to increase surfactant production in the fetus. What is the mechanism of action of this substance?

choices.text: Breaks the structure of water in alveoli
Lubricate the flow of CO2 diffusion

questions.solution:
The mechanism of action of surfactant is by breaking the structure of water in alveoli.

When water forms a surface with air, the water molecules on the surface of the alveoli have a strong attraction for one another. This pulls the molecules together, leading to high surface tension.

The surfactant is amphipathic in nature (i.e., hydrophobic on one end and hydrophilic on the other). They align themselves on the alveolar surface, with their hydrophobic portions facing the alveolar lumen.

The cohesive force between a water molecule and an adjacent pulmonary surfactant molecule is very low. So, they break up the attracting forces between water molecules lining the alveoli (which had been responsible for the high surface tension). Thus, they reduce surface tension.

questions.text: Stability of alveoli is maintained by______.

choices.text: Increased alveolar surface area by surfactant

questions.solution:
Stability of alveoli is maintained by increased alveolar surface area by surfactant.

Surfactant reduces the lung's tendency to recoil so that they do not collapse easily and so the stability of the alveoli is maintained.

Factors that maintain alveolar stability

  • Pulmonary surfactant: ↓ surface tension within alveoli
  • Mechanical interdependence: prevents alveolar collapse

Interdependence

The tendency of one alveolus to collapse is opposed by the traction exerted by the surrounding alveoli. Thus, the collapse of a single alveolus stretches and distorts the surrounding alveoli, which in turn are connected to other alveoli. This support offered to lung units by those surrounding them is termed Interdependence.

questions.text: A woman at risk for preterm delivery is planned for assessment of fetal lung maturity. At what gestational age will the surfactants be detectable in the amniotic fluid?
questions.solution:
Surfactant appears in the amniotic fluid between 28 and 32 weeks of gestation. 

By week 20-24, primitive alveoli form and surfactant production begins but it does not reach the surface of the lungs until later.

Mature levels of pulmonary surfactant are present usually after 35 wk of gestation.

Clinical aspects :

  • Preterm infants develop respiratory distress syndrome or hyaline membrane disease due to surfactant deficiency.
  • Antenatal corticosteroids are given to increase the production of surfactants.
  • Lecithin/Sphingomyelin ratio is a test for fetal lung maturity. L/S ratio > 2 is suggestive of a mature fetal lung.

questions.text: A woman on multiple medications came for an antenatal check-up. Which among the following medications that she takes decreases surfactant production?
questions.solution:
Inadequate Insulin intake in diabetic pregnant causes inadequate glucose control. This causes excess glucose in maternal plasma, crossing Placenta. Excess glucose in fetal plasma causes fetal pancreas to hypersecrete fetal Insulin. 

Excess insulin in fetal plasma decreases surfactant production. This is the reason for the increased incidence of hyaline membrane disease in infants of diabetic mothers.

Factors increasing surfactant synthesis: 

  • Glucocorticoids
  • Thyroxine
  • Stretching of lungs in infancy
  • Beta adrenergic agonist
  • Calcium
  • Regular exercise.

Factors decreasing surfactant synthesis: 

  • Smoking
  • Long term inhalation of 100% oxygen
  • Occlusion of main bronchus/pulmonary artery.

questions.text: Which is the best metabolic function of the lung?

choices.text: Conversion of angiotensin I to angiotensin II

questions.solution:
Conversion of angiotensin I to angiotensin II is the most significant metabolic function of the lungs.

This is mediated by angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE), located on the surface of endothelial cells in the pulmonary capillaries.

  • Synthesized and used in the lungs
    • Surfactant
  • Synthesized or stored and released into the blood
    • Prostaglandins
    • Histamine
    • Kallikrein
  • Partially removed from the blood
    • Prostaglandins
